snippet: A result of exporting so many players — more than 2,700 Argentines now play in foreign leagues — is that club soccer in the South American nation is blighted by a lack of continuity.
abstract: National soccer leagues in Argentina are suffering financial scandals, crowd trouble and the lure of riches abroad that have fueled a talent exodus; powerful feeder system sends promising players to Europe as teenagers, with more than 2,700 Argentines now playing in foreign leagues; result is that domestic fans have fewer and fewer chances to cheer their favorite players.
lead_paragraph: A result of exporting so many players — more than 2,700 Argentines now play in foreign leagues — is that club soccer in the South American nation is blighted by a lack of continuity.

headline.main: Argentina’s Feeder System Drains Talent From Nation’s Top Division
headline.print_headline: Argentina’s Feeder System Drains Talent From Nation’s Top Division
